pageContext.description:
The panel shows a bearded man with a hooked nose under an arch, facing to the left. A building with a tower and arched entrance is visible in the background above his proper left shoulder. The panel appears to be a fragment of a larger composition.
[cda 2019]

metadata.title: Portrait of a Bearded Man

pageContext.provenance:
- David Goldmann, Vienna
- seized from the above by Hitler’s agents and allocated in the central depot of the Kunsthistorisches Museum, Vienna (inv. D.G. 2), where it was reserved for the Führermuseum
- transferred to Alt Ausse (inv. no. 4699) for the Kunstmuseum Linz (inv. no. 2635, as German/upper Austrian 16th century)
- recovered by the Allied Forces on 15 October 1945 and sent to the Munich Central Collecting Point (inv. no. 9479, as South German, manner of Schauffelein)
- given over to the Austrian Government Kremsmünster depot (inv. no. K1366) on 25 April 1946
- restituted to David Goldmann
- thence by descent to the present owner
- sold at Sotheby’s New York, 06.06.2013, lot no. 103
[Sotheby's online database: http://www.sothebys.com/en/auctions/ecatalogue/2013/old-master-paintings-n09003/lot.103.html?locale=en; accessed 13.08.2019]
- private collection, Germany
- auctioned at Dorotheum, Vienna, 17.10.2017, lot 211
- private collection
[Dorotheum online database: https://www.dorotheum.com/de/l/460438/; accessed 01.09.2020]

tests.text: - the support is a thin soft wood panel

The infrared refectogram shows:

- changes made to the position of the man's pupil, which was originally looking to the right  

- a thin underdrawing probably executed with black chalk

Using non-invasive methods of examination azurite could be found in the sky and the man's sleeve, where it is mixed with lead white


[Dorotheum online database: https://www.dorotheum.com/de/l/460438/; accessed 01.09.2020]
